title: RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Protocol 8: CTAB/Acid Phenol/Silica Membrane Method
title_html: RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Protocol 8: CTAB/Acid Phenol/Silica Membrane Method

source.description: Grind tissue to a powder in liquid nitrogen.

Add
–

of pre-heated
extraction buffer
in a 2 ml microcentrifuge tube.
Vortex the tube until the tissue is mixed with the buffer.

source.body: To facilitate mixing, you may have to invert the tube on the vortex, and/or heat it briefly in a water bath.

source.body: All of the insoluble matter should form a pellet at the bottom of the tube.

source.description: Pour the supernatant into a new 2 ml tube.

source.body: Most of the chlorophyll will be dissolved in the lower, organic phase.

source.description: Transfer the upper, aqueous phase to a new 2 ml tube, using a disposable pipette.

source.body: Avoid transferring any of the material (usually a white precipitate) from the boundary between the phases.

source.description: Estimate the volume of the aqueous phase based on the markings on the tube.
Estimate the new total volume in the tube.
Pour the contents of the tube into a Qiagen miniRNA spin column (pink), until the column is almost filled with liquid.

at >

source.body: The column should be empty at the end of this spin.

source.description: Discard the flow-through from the collection tube.
Repeat the previous two steps with the same miniRNA spin column, until all of the liquid in the tube(s) has been passed through the column.

source.body: The nucleic acid is now bound to the silica membrane in the spin column.

Add
of RNase-free water to the column.

Spin at maximum speed for
to elute.
Add at least 0.5 volumes of solution RLT, and mix by briefly shaking.
Add 0.5 volumes of 95–100 % ethanol.
Mix by briefly shaking.

Spin at maximum speed for
to remove remaining liquid from the silica membrane.

description:
Implemented by: Michael Deyholos
This protocol combines elements of standard CTAB, acid phenol, and silica-membrane protocols.
The protocol was developed to extract total RNA from a wide range of plant species and tissues, and to do so in the smallest volume possible to yield >20 μg of total RNA using as little as 50 mg of fresh tissue. Maintaining a small extraction volume also allows for many samples to be processed in parallel in microcentrifuge tubes;
at least 12 samples can be processed in 3–4 hours.
The protocol has been used successfully with dozens of species, including tissues rich in polysaccharides and/or secondary metabolites. There are four organic extractions in total (three chloroform and one phenol:chloroform).
For many species/tissues, the full set of chloroform extractions in the order specified is required to maximize RNA purity and to prevent phase inversion during the acid phenol extraction.
This protocol is part of a collection of eighteen protocols used to isolate total RNA from plant tissue. (RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Collection: https://www.protocols.io/view/rna-isolation-from-plant-tissue-439gyr6)
